newsitem.title: USA: AOL launches instant Internet messages.
newsitem.headline: AOL launches instant Internet messages.

text.p: America Online Inc. said Thursday it is offering its "instant messaging" software, previously available only to AOL users, to all Internet users, by downloading the software at its Web site.

The software, which is currently in beta, or customer testing, lets users send and respond to messages immediately, while a "Buddy List" feature tells users who among a designated list of users is online.
AOL said the software, which runs on the Internet backbone and not on AOLNet, AOL's proprietary network, can handle millions of simultaneous users.

"This technology was designed to scale to millions and millions of users," said David Gang, senior vice president, product marketing, AOL Networks, adding that AOL has not yet decided on whether it will charge for the final product in the future.
"For the time being, this is the beta programme. It could be free, we could charge for it, who knows," he said.
AOL said that users of any online service or any Internet access provider can use the software to communicate with friends who are using the Instant Messenger.

Internet users can download a limited availability beta release from AOL's Web site at http://www.aol.com. The limited beta release of Instant Messenger is available only on Windows 95. Windows 3.1, Macintosh and Java versions will follow.
AOL's stock rose $2 to $51.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
